title: Definition: Binomial Coefficient
text:
The binomial coefficient \(\binom{n}{k}\) (read “n choose k”) counts the number of ways to choose \(k\) objects from \(n\) objects without regard to order.


For non-negative integers \(n\) and \(k\) with \(k \leq n\), the binomial coefficient is defined as:
\[\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}\]
where \(n!\) denotes the factorial of \(n\).




In terms of Combination: \(\binom{n}{k} = C(n,k)\) - the number of k-combinations from n elements
In terms of Permutation: \(\binom{n}{k} = \frac{P(n,k)}{k!}\) where \(P(n,k)\) is the number of k-permutations
Recursive definition: \[\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}\] with base cases \(\binom{n}{0} = \binom{n}{n} = 1\)





\(\binom{n}{0} = 1\) (one way to choose nothing)
\(\binom{n}{1} = n\) (n ways to choose one item)
\(\binom{n}{n} = 1\) (one way to choose everything)
\(\binom{n}{k} = 0\) if \(k > n\) (cannot choose more items than available)





Symmetry: \(\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n}{n-k}\)
Pascal’s Identity: \(\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}\)
Binomial Theorem: \((x + y)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^k y^{n-k}\)





Counting subsets of a given size
Expansion of binomial expressions
Probability calculations in discrete distributions
Pascal’s triangle construction
Generating Functions - binomial coefficients appear naturally in both ordinary and exponential generating functions
Inclusion-Exclusion Principle - uses binomial coefficients in its proof and applications

title: Example: Pascal’s Triangle
text:
Pascal’s Triangle is a triangular array of Binomial Coefficient s that provides a visual representation of many combinatorial properties.


The triangle is constructed with the following rules: 1. The top row (row 0) contains just the number 1 2. Each subsequent row starts and ends with 1 3. Each interior number is the sum of the two numbers above it
Row 0:           1
Row 1:         1   1
Row 2:       1   2   1
Row 3:     1   3   3   1
Row 4:   1   4   6   4   1
Row 5: 1   5  10  10   5   1



The entry in row \(n\) and position \(k\) (counting from 0) is exactly \(\binom{n}{k}\):

Row 0: \(\binom{0}{0} = 1\)
Row 1: \(\binom{1}{0} = 1\), \(\binom{1}{1} = 1\)
Row 2: \(\binom{2}{0} = 1\), \(\binom{2}{1} = 2\), \(\binom{2}{2} = 1\)
Row 3: \(\binom{3}{0} = 1\), \(\binom{3}{1} = 3\), \(\binom{3}{2} = 3\), \(\binom{3}{3} = 1\)





Symmetry: Each row is symmetric, reflecting \(\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n}{n-k}\)
Row Sums: The sum of row \(n\) is \(2^n\): \[\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} = 2^n\]
Hockey Stick Pattern: The sum along any diagonal equals the entry below and to the side: \[\sum_{i=r}^{n} \binom{i}{r} = \binom{n+1}{r+1}\]
Fibonacci Numbers: The sums of the shallow diagonals give Fibonacci numbers





Binomial Expansion: Row \(n\) gives the coefficients of \((x+y)^n\)
Probability: Used in calculating binomial probabilities
Combinatorial Identities: Visual proofs of many identities
Number Theory: Connections to divisibility properties




The entries in Pascal’s Triangle can be generated using a power series: \[\frac{1}{(1-x)^{n+1}} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \binom{n+k}{k} x^k\]

title: Definition: Tree
text:
A tree is a connected graph with no cycles. It is one of the most fundamental structures in graph theory and has numerous applications in mathematics and computer science.


A graph \(T = (V, E)\) is a tree if and only if: 1. \(T\) is connected (there exists a path between any two vertices) 2. \(T\) is acyclic (contains no cycles)



For a graph \(T\) with \(n\) vertices, the following statements are equivalent:

\(T\) is a tree
\(T\) is connected and has exactly \(n - 1\) edges
\(T\) is acyclic and has exactly \(n - 1\) edges
There is exactly one path between any two vertices in \(T\)
\(T\) is connected, but removing any edge disconnects it
\(T\) is acyclic, but adding any edge creates exactly one cycle







Edge Count: A tree with \(n\) vertices has exactly \(n - 1\) edges
Leaf Vertices: Every tree with at least two vertices has at least two leaves (vertices of degree 1)
Unique Path: Between any two vertices in a tree, there exists exactly one path
Bipartite: Every tree is a bipartite graph (vertices can be colored with two colors such that no adjacent vertices share the same color)





Deletion Property: Removing any edge from a tree disconnects it into exactly two components
Addition Property: Adding any edge to a tree creates exactly one cycle
Degree Sum: For a tree with \(n\) vertices: \(\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2(n - 1)\)







A rooted tree is a tree with one designated vertex called the root. This imposes a hierarchical structure where: - Each vertex has a unique parent (except the root) - Vertices may have zero or more children - Leaves are vertices with no children



A rooted tree where each vertex has at most two children, typically designated as left and right children.



Given a connected graph \(G\), a spanning tree is a subgraph that: - Includes all vertices of \(G\) - Is a tree






The path graph \(P_n\) with vertices \(\{1, 2, ..., n\}\) and edges \(\{(i, i+1) : 1 \leq i < n\}\) is a tree.



The star graph \(S_n\) with: - Central vertex \(c\) - \(n\) other vertices \(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n\) - Edges connecting \(c\) to each \(v_i\)



A complete binary tree of height \(h\) has: - \(2^{h+1} - 1\) vertices - \(2^h\) leaves - Internal vertices with exactly two children (except possibly at the last level)




Trees are fundamental in:

Computer Science:

Data structures (binary search trees, heaps, B-trees)
Algorithms (spanning tree algorithms, decision trees)
File systems and directory structures

Mathematics:

Combinatorial enumeration (Cayley’s formula: \(n^{n-2}\) labeled trees on \(n\) vertices)
Tree counting via generating functions
Optimization (minimum spanning trees)
Algebraic structures (tree decompositions)

Real-world Applications:

Family trees and genealogy
Organizational hierarchies
Network routing and broadcasting







A forest is an acyclic graph, equivalently a disjoint union of trees.



The center of a tree consists of the vertex or vertices with minimum eccentricity (maximum distance to any other vertex).



The diameter of a tree is the length of the longest path between any two vertices.

title: Definition: Graph
text:
A graph is a mathematical structure consisting of a Set of vertices (also called nodes) and a set of edges that connect pairs of vertices.


A graph \(G\) is an ordered pair \(G = (V, E)\) where: - \(V\) is a finite non-empty set of vertices - \(E\) is a set of edges, where each edge connects two vertices


In an undirected graph, edges have no direction. Formally: - \(E \subseteq \{\{u, v\} : u, v \in V, u \neq v\}\) - Each edge is an unordered pair of distinct vertices



In a directed graph, edges have direction. Formally: - \(E \subseteq V \times V\) - Each edge (or arc) is an ordered pair \((u, v)\) where \(u\) is the tail and \(v\) is the head





Vertices: Denoted as \(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n\) or simply \(1, 2, ..., n\)
Edges: In undirected graphs: \(\{u, v\}\) or \(uv\); in directed graphs: \((u, v)\) or \(u \to v\)
Adjacent vertices: Two vertices \(u\) and \(v\) are adjacent if there is an edge between them
Incident edge: An edge is incident to a vertex if the vertex is one of its endpoints
Degree: The degree of a vertex \(v\), denoted \(\deg(v)\), is the number of edges incident to \(v\)

In directed graphs: in-degree \(\deg^-(v)\) and out-degree \(\deg^+(v)\)








The sum of all vertex degrees equals twice the cardinality of the edge set: \(\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2|E|\)
The number of vertices with odd degree is even
Graph automorphisms are permutations of vertices that preserve adjacency





The sum of all in-degrees equals the sum of all out-degrees: \(\sum_{v \in V} \deg^-(v) = \sum_{v \in V} \deg^+(v) = |E|\) (the cardinality of the edge set)






Simple Graph: No loops (edges from a vertex to itself) and no multiple edges between the same pair of vertices
Multigraph: Allows multiple edges between the same pair of vertices
Complete Graph \(K_n\): Every pair of distinct vertices is connected by an edge
Bipartite Graph: Vertices can be divided into two disjoint sets such that no edge connects vertices within the same set
Tree: A connected graph with no cycles






\(G = (V, E)\) where: - \(V = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}\) - \(E = \{\{1, 2\}, \{2, 3\}, \{3, 4\}, \{1, 4\}\}\)
This forms a cycle of length 4.



\(G = (V, E)\) where: - \(V = \{A, B, C\}\) - \(E = \{(A, B), (B, C), (C, A)\}\)
This forms a directed cycle.



The complete graph on 4 vertices has \(\binom{4}{2} = 6\) edges.




Graphs are fundamental in: - Computer networks (vertices as computers, edges as connections) - Social networks (vertices as people, edges as relationships) - Transportation systems (vertices as locations, edges as routes) - Circuit design (vertices as components, edges as connections)

Vertices: Denoted as \(v_1, v_2, ..., v_n\) or simply \(1, 2, ..., n\)
Edges: In undirected graphs: \(\{u, v\}\) or \(uv\); in directed graphs: \((u, v)\) or \(u \to v\)
Adjacent vertices: Two vertices \(u\) and \(v\) are adjacent if there is an edge between them
Incident edge: An edge is incident to a vertex if the vertex is one of its endpoints
Degree: The degree of a vertex \(v\), denoted \(\deg(v)\), is the number of edges incident to \(v\)

In directed graphs: in-degree \(\deg^-(v)\) and out-degree \(\deg^+(v)\)

title: Definition: Graph
text:
The sum of all vertex degrees equals twice the cardinality of the edge set: \(\sum_{v \in V} \deg(v) = 2|E|\)
The number of vertices with odd degree is even
Graph automorphisms are permutations of vertices that preserve adjacency





The sum of all in-degrees equals the sum of all out-degrees: \(\sum_{v \in V} \deg^-(v) = \sum_{v \in V} \deg^+(v) = |E|\) (the cardinality of the edge set)

title: Definition: Graph
text:
Simple Graph: No loops (edges from a vertex to itself) and no multiple edges between the same pair of vertices
Multigraph: Allows multiple edges between the same pair of vertices
Complete Graph \(K_n\): Every pair of distinct vertices is connected by an edge
Bipartite Graph: Vertices can be divided into two disjoint sets such that no edge connects vertices within the same set
Tree: A connected graph with no cycles

title: Definition: Graph
text:
\(G = (V, E)\) where: - \(V = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}\) - \(E = \{\{1, 2\}, \{2, 3\}, \{3, 4\}, \{1, 4\}\}\)
This forms a cycle of length 4.



\(G = (V, E)\) where: - \(V = \{A, B, C\}\) - \(E = \{(A, B), (B, C), (C, A)\}\)
This forms a directed cycle.



The complete graph on 4 vertices has \(\binom{4}{2} = 6\) edges.

title: Definition: Graph
text: Graphs are fundamental in: - Computer networks (vertices as computers, edges as connections) - Social networks (vertices as people, edges as relationships) - Transportation systems (vertices as locations, edges as routes) - Circuit design (vertices as components, edges as connections)

title: Theorem: Pigeonhole Principle
text:
The Pigeonhole Principle is a fundamental counting principle stating that if you distribute more items than containers, at least one container must contain more than one item.


Basic Form: If \(n\) items are placed into \(k\) containers where \(n > k\), then at least one container must contain more than one item.
General Form: If \(n\) items are placed into \(k\) containers, then at least one container must contain at least \(\lceil n/k \rceil\) items.



Let \(f: A \to B\) be a function where \(A\) and \(B\) are finite Sets with cardinalities satisfying \(|A| > |B|\). Then \(f\) is not injective; that is, there exist distinct elements \(a_1, a_2 \in A\) such that \(f(a_1) = f(a_2)\).



By contradiction. Suppose \(f\) is injective. Then each element of \(A\) maps to a distinct element of \(B\), implying \(|A| \leq |B|\). This contradicts our assumption that \(|A| > |B|\).




Infinite Version: An infinite set cannot be mapped injectively into a finite set.
Probabilistic Version: If items are distributed randomly, the expected number of items in each container provides bounds on the maximum load.
Multidimensional Version: Extends to partitioning higher-dimensional spaces.





Existence Proofs: Often used to prove that certain configurations must exist
Computer Science: Hash table collision analysis, load balancing
Number Theory: Proving properties about integer sequences
Graph Theory: Showing certain substructures must exist in large graphs





In any group of 13 people, at least two must have birthdays in the same month
Among any 6 people, either 3 are mutual friends or 3 are mutual strangers
In any sequence of \(n^2 + 1\) distinct real numbers, there is either an increasing subsequence or a decreasing subsequence of length \(n + 1\)





Inclusion-Exclusion Principle: Another fundamental counting principle for finding the size of unions of sets
Binomial Coefficient: For counting combinations and subsets

title: Theorem: Euler’s Theorem
text:
For any integer \(a\) coprime to \(n\), we have \(a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\) (see Congruence), where \(\phi(n)\) is Euler’s totient function.


Let \(n \geq 1\) be an integer and let \(a\) be an integer with \(\gcd(a, n) = 1\). Then: \[a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}\]
where \(\phi(n)\) counts the number of integers \(k\) with \(1 \leq k \leq n\) and \(\gcd(k, n) = 1\).



For a positive integer \(n\): - If \(n = p\) is Prime Number, then \(\phi(p) = p - 1\) - If \(n = p^k\), then \(\phi(p^k) = p^k - p^{k-1} = p^{k-1}(p - 1)\) - If \(\gcd(m, n) = 1\), then \(\phi(mn) = \phi(m)\phi(n)\) (multiplicative)



The integers coprime to \(n\) form a Group under multiplication modulo \(n\), denoted \((\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^*\). This is the group of units of the Quotient Group \(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}\) (see Example: Integers Modulo n). This group has order \(\phi(n)\), so by Lagrange’s theorem, any element raised to the group order equals the identity.




Fermat’s Little Theorem: When \(n = p\) is prime, \(\phi(p) = p - 1\), giving \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\)
Carmichael’s Theorem: A refinement using the Carmichael function \(\lambda(n)\)





RSA cryptography (uses Chinese Remainder Theorem for efficient decryption)
Primality testing
Computing modular inverses: \(a^{\phi(n)-1} \equiv a^{-1} \pmod{n}\)

title: Theorem: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
text:
Every natural number greater than 1 can be represented uniquely as a product of Prime Number numbers, up to the order of factors.


For every natural number \(n > 1\), there exist unique prime numbers \(p_1 < p_2 < \cdots < p_k\) and positive integers \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_k\) such that: \[n = p_1^{a_1} \cdot p_2^{a_2} \cdot \ldots \cdot p_k^{a_k}\]
This representation is called the prime factorization of \(n\).



The theorem consists of two claims:

Existence: Every \(n > 1\) has at least one prime factorization
Uniqueness: The prime factorization is unique (up to ordering)




Existence (by strong induction): - Base case: \(n = 2\) is prime, so \(n = 2^1\) - Inductive step: If \(n\) is prime, we’re done. Otherwise, \(n = ab\) where \(1 < a, b < n\) - By induction hypothesis, both \(a\) and \(b\) have prime factorizations - Combining these gives a prime factorization of \(n\)
Uniqueness (by contradiction): - Suppose \(n\) has two different prime factorizations - Using the prime property (if \(p \mid ab\), then \(p \mid a\) or \(p \mid b\)) - Show that every prime in one factorization must appear in the other - The exponents must also match




\(12 = 2^2 \cdot 3^1\)
\(30 = 2^1 \cdot 3^1 \cdot 5^1\)
\(100 = 2^2 \cdot 5^2\)
\(17 = 17^1\) (prime numbers have trivial factorization)




The fundamental theorem enables: - Greatest common divisor (GCD) calculations (see Greatest Common Divisor) - Least common multiple (LCM) calculations (see Least Common Multiple) - Rational number arithmetic - Many results in algebraic number theory
This theorem justifies calling primes the “building blocks” of the natural numbers.

title: Theorem: Fermat’s Little Theorem
text:
If \(p\) is a prime number, then for any integer \(a\) not divisible by \(p\), we have \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\) (see Congruence).


Let \(p\) be a prime number and let \(a\) be an integer such that \(\gcd(a, p) = 1\) (see Greatest Common Divisor). Then: \[a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\]
Equivalently, for any integer \(a\): \[a^p \equiv a \pmod{p}\]



Pierre de Fermat stated this theorem in a letter dated October 18, 1640, to his friend and confidant Frénicle de Bessy. Fermat did not publish a proof, and the first published proof was given by Leonhard Euler in 1736.

By the binomial theorem: \[(a+1)^p = \sum_{k=0}^{p} \binom{p}{k} a^k\]
For \(0 < k < p\), the binomial coefficient \(\binom{p}{k} = \frac{p!}{k!(p-k)!}\) is divisible by \(p\) because \(p\) divides the numerator but not the denominator.
Therefore: \[(a+1)^p \equiv a^p + 1 \equiv a + 1 \pmod{p}\]



The non-zero residues modulo \(p\) form a group of order \(p-1\) under multiplication. By Lagrange’s theorem, any element of this group raised to the order of the group equals the identity element. Hence \(a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod{p}\) for any \(a\) coprime to \(p\).

We need to show \(n^5 \equiv n\) modulo \(2\), \(3\), and \(5\)
By Fermat’s Little Theorem: \(n^2 \equiv n \pmod{2}\), \(n^3 \equiv n \pmod{3}\), \(n^5 \equiv n \pmod{5}\)
Since \(n^5 - n = n(n^4 - 1) = n(n^2-1)(n^2+1)\), the divisibility by \(2\) and \(3\) follows

title: Theorem: Euclidean Algorithm
text:
The Euclidean algorithm provides an efficient method for computing the greatest common divisor of two integers.


Let \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}\) with \(b \neq 0\). Then: \[\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a \bmod b)\]
where \(a \bmod b\) is the remainder when \(a\) is divided by \(b\). This remainder is the representative of the equivalence class of \(a\) in the quotient \(\mathbb{Z}/b\mathbb{Z}\) (see Example: Integers Modulo n).



Given integers \(a\) and \(b\) with \(a \geq b > 0\):

If \(b = 0\), then \(\gcd(a, b) = a\)
Otherwise, compute \(r = a \bmod b\)
Replace \((a, b)\) with \((b, r)\) and repeat

The algorithm terminates when the remainder becomes 0.



We need to show that \(\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, a \bmod b)\).
Let \(r = a \bmod b\). Then \(a = qb + r\) for some integer \(q\).
Step 1: Show that any common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\) is also a common divisor of \(b\) and \(r\).
If \(d \mid a\) and \(d \mid b\), then \(d \mid (a - qb) = r\). Thus \(d\) divides both \(b\) and \(r\).
Step 2: Show that any common divisor of \(b\) and \(r\) is also a common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\).
If \(d \mid b\) and \(d \mid r\), then \(d \mid (qb + r) = a\). Thus \(d\) divides both \(a\) and \(b\).
Therefore, the set of common divisors of \((a, b)\) equals the set of common divisors of \((b, r)\), so their greatest elements are equal.



Find \(\gcd(48, 18)\):

\(48 = 2 \cdot 18 + 12\), so \(\gcd(48, 18) = \gcd(18, 12)\)
\(18 = 1 \cdot 12 + 6\), so \(\gcd(18, 12) = \gcd(12, 6)\)
\(12 = 2 \cdot 6 + 0\), so \(\gcd(12, 6) = 6\)

Therefore, \(\gcd(48, 18) = 6\).



The algorithm can be extended to find integers \(x, y\) such that: \[\gcd(a, b) = ax + by\]
This proves Bézout’s identity constructively.



The number of steps is at most \(O(\log \min(a, b))\), making it very efficient even for large numbers.

title: Theorem: Euclid’s Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
text:
There are infinitely many prime numbers.


For any finite list of prime numbers \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\), there exists a prime number not in this list. Therefore, the set of prime numbers is infinite.



Euclid’s original formulation (circa 300 BCE) was: “Prime numbers are more than any assigned multitude of prime numbers.” The ancient Greeks did not have our modern concept of infinity, so Euclid could not have written “there are infinitely many primes.”



Euclid’s Original Proof:
Let \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\) be any finite list of prime numbers. Consider the number: \[P = p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n + 1\]
Now we consider two cases:
Case 1: \(P\) is prime. Then \(P\) is a prime number that is not in our original list (since \(P > p_i\) for all \(i\)).
Case 2: \(P\) is composite. By the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, \(P\) has a prime divisor, say \(p\). We claim that \(p\) cannot be any of \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\).
If \(p = p_i\) for some \(i\), then \(p_i\) divides both \(P\) and \(p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n\). Therefore, \(p_i\) would divide their difference: \[P - p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n = 1\]
But no prime divides 1, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, \(p\) is a prime not in our original list.
In both cases, we have found a prime not in the original list, proving that any finite list of primes is incomplete.



It is often mistakenly thought that Euclid’s proof shows that \(P = p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n + 1\) is always prime. This is false. For example: - \(2 \cdot 3 + 1 = 7\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 + 1 = 31\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 + 1 = 211\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 + 1 = 2311\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13 + 1 = 30031 = 59 \times 509\) (composite)
The proof only requires that \(P\) has a prime divisor not in the original list.



Factorial Proof:
For any positive integer \(n\), consider \(n! + 1\). This number is not divisible by any integer from 2 to \(n\) (it leaves remainder 1 when divided by each). Therefore, \(n! + 1\) is either: - Prime (and greater than \(n\)), or - Divisible by a prime greater than \(n\)
Either way, for every \(n\), there exists a prime greater than \(n\), proving infinitude.



Euclid’s theorem is one of the most elegant proofs in mathematics and has inspired numerous variations: - Over 200 different proofs have been discovered - It exemplifies the power of proof by contradiction - It motivates deeper questions about prime distribution (Prime Number Theorem, Riemann Hypothesis) - The construction \(p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n + 1\) appears in various areas of number theory




Dirichlet’s Theorem: There are infinitely many primes in any arithmetic progression \(a + nd\) where \(\gcd(a,d) = 1\)
Prime Number Theorem: The number of primes less than \(x\) is approximately \(x/\ln(x)\)
Bertrand’s Postulate: For every \(n > 1\), there exists a prime \(p\) such that \(n < p < 2n\)

But no prime divides 1, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, \(p\) is a prime not in our original list.
In both cases, we have found a prime not in the original list, proving that any finite list of primes is incomplete.

title: Theorem: Euclid’s Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
text:
It is often mistakenly thought that Euclid’s proof shows that \(P = p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n + 1\) is always prime. This is false. For example: - \(2 \cdot 3 + 1 = 7\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 + 1 = 31\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 + 1 = 211\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 + 1 = 2311\) (prime) - \(2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13 + 1 = 30031 = 59 \times 509\) (composite)
The proof only requires that \(P\) has a prime divisor not in the original list.

title: Theorem: Euclid’s Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
text:
Factorial Proof:
For any positive integer \(n\), consider \(n! + 1\). This number is not divisible by any integer from 2 to \(n\) (it leaves remainder 1 when divided by each). Therefore, \(n! + 1\) is either: - Prime (and greater than \(n\)), or - Divisible by a prime greater than \(n\)
Either way, for every \(n\), there exists a prime greater than \(n\), proving infinitude.

title: Theorem: Euclid’s Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
text: Euclid’s theorem is one of the most elegant proofs in mathematics and has inspired numerous variations: - Over 200 different proofs have been discovered - It exemplifies the power of proof by contradiction - It motivates deeper questions about prime distribution (Prime Number Theorem, Riemann Hypothesis) - The construction \(p_1 \cdot p_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot p_n + 1\) appears in various areas of number theory

title: Theorem: Euclid’s Theorem on the Infinitude of Primes
text:
Dirichlet’s Theorem: There are infinitely many primes in any arithmetic progression \(a + nd\) where \(\gcd(a,d) = 1\)
Prime Number Theorem: The number of primes less than \(x\) is approximately \(x/\ln(x)\)
Bertrand’s Postulate: For every \(n > 1\), there exists a prime \(p\) such that \(n < p < 2n\)

title: Definition: Divisibility
text:
Let \(a\) and \(b\) be integers with \(a \neq 0\). We say that \(a\) divides \(b\) (or \(b\) is divisible by \(a\)) if there exists an integer \(k\) such that \(b = ak\).


When \(a\) divides \(b\), we write: \[a \mid b\]
When \(a\) does not divide \(b\), we write: \[a \nmid b\]



When \(a \mid b\), we also say: - \(a\) is a divisor (or factor) of \(b\) - \(b\) is a multiple of \(a\) - \(b\) is divisible by \(a\)




Reflexivity: For any non-zero integer \(a\): \(a \mid a\)
Transitivity: If \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid c\), then \(a \mid c\)
Linear Combination: If \(a \mid b\) and \(a \mid c\), then for any integers \(x, y\): \[a \mid (bx + cy)\]
Antisymmetry: If \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid a\), then \(a = \pm b\)
Ordering: If \(a \mid b\) and both \(a, b > 0\), then \(a \leq b\)
Product Rule: If \(a \mid b\) and \(c \mid d\), then \(ac \mid bd\)







\(3 \mid 12\) because \(12 = 3 \times 4\)
\(-5 \mid 20\) because \(20 = (-5) \times (-4)\)
\(1 \mid n\) for any integer \(n\)
\(n \mid 0\) for any non-zero integer \(n\)





\(4 \nmid 7\) because there is no integer \(k\) such that \(7 = 4k\)
\(0 \nmid 5\) (division by zero is undefined)






Unity: \(1\) divides every integer
Zero: Every non-zero integer divides \(0\)
Self-divisibility: Every non-zero integer divides itself




The divisibility relation on positive integers forms a partial order: - Reflexive: \(a \mid a\) for all positive integers \(a\) - Antisymmetric: If \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid a\) for positive integers, then \(a = b\) - Transitive: If \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid c\), then \(a \mid c\)
Note that this is not a total order since not all pairs of positive integers are comparable under divisibility (e.g., neither \(2 \mid 3\) nor \(3 \mid 2\)).



The divisibility relation is closely connected to the division algorithm. Given integers \(a\) and \(b\) with \(b > 0\), by the division algorithm: \[a = bq + r \quad \text{where } 0 \leq r < b\]
Then \(b \mid a\) if and only if \(r = 0\).



Divisibility is fundamental to: - Defining prime numbers - Computing the greatest common divisor - Understanding congruences - The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic

title: Definition: Morphism
text:
A morphism (also called an arrow) is a fundamental concept in Category theory representing a structure-preserving map between objects. When viewing a category as a Directed Graph, morphisms are the directed edges between vertices (objects).


In a Category \(\mathcal{C}\), a morphism \(f: A \to B\) consists of: - A domain (or source) object \(A\) - A codomain (or target) object \(B\) - An abstract “arrow” \(f\) from \(A\) to \(B\)



For morphisms in a category, we have:

Composition: If \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to C\), then there exists a composite morphism \(g \circ f: A \to C\)
Identity: For each object \(A\), there exists an identity morphism \(\text{id}_A: A \to A\)
Associativity: \((h \circ g) \circ f = h \circ (g \circ f)\) whenever the compositions are defined
Identity laws: \(f \circ \text{id}_A = f\) and \(\text{id}_B \circ f = f\) for \(f: A \to B\)




The collection of all morphisms from \(A\) to \(B\) in category \(\mathcal{C}\) is denoted: - \(\text{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\) or - \(\mathcal{C}(A, B)\) or - \(\text{Mor}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\)



Special types of morphisms include: - Monomorphism: A categorical generalization of injective functions - Epimorphism: A categorical generalization of surjective functions - Isomorphism: A morphism with a two-sided inverse

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text:
An epimorphism (also called an epic morphism or simply epi) is a morphism in a category that satisfies the right-cancellation property.


In a category \(\mathcal{C}\), a morphism \(f: A \to B\) is an epimorphism if for any object \(C\) and any pair of morphisms \(g, h: B \to C\), the following implication holds:
\[g \circ f = h \circ f \implies g = h\]
In other words, \(f\) is right-cancellative: it can be “cancelled” from the right side of an equation.



A morphism \(f: A \to B\) is an epimorphism if and only if for every object \(C\), the induced function \[f^*: \text{Hom}(B, C) \to \text{Hom}(A, C)\] defined by \(f^*(g) = g \circ f\) is injective.






Set: In the category of sets, epimorphisms are exactly the surjective functions
Grp: In the category of groups, epimorphisms are the surjective group homomorphisms
Top: In the category of topological spaces, epimorphisms are the continuous maps with dense image
Vect: In the category of vector spaces over a field, epimorphisms are the surjective linear transformations
Ab: In the category of abelian groups, epimorphisms are the surjective group homomorphisms




Not all epimorphisms are surjective in the usual sense:

Ring: In the category of rings, the inclusion \(\mathbb{Z} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{Q}\) is an epimorphism (as a ring homomorphism) but not surjective
Haus: In the category of Hausdorff spaces, the inclusion \(\mathbb{Q} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is an epimorphism (dense image) but not surjective
Mon: In the category of monoids, there exist non-surjective epimorphisms








Composition: The composition of two epimorphisms is an epimorphism
Identity: Every identity morphism is an epimorphism
Decomposition: If \(g \circ f\) is an epimorphism, then \(g\) is an epimorphism





Retractions: Every retraction (right inverse) is an epimorphism
Isomorphisms: Every isomorphism is both a monomorphism and an epimorphism
Coequalizers: Every coequalizer is an epimorphism





In categories with additional structure, we can define special types of epimorphisms:

Regular epimorphism: A coequalizer of some pair of parallel morphisms
Strong epimorphism: An epimorphism that has the right lifting property with respect to monomorphisms
Extremal epimorphism: An epimorphism that doesn’t factor through any proper monomorphism
Split epimorphism: An epimorphism that has a right inverse (i.e., a retraction)




Epimorphisms are fundamental in category theory because:

They generalize the notion of “surjective” to arbitrary categories
They are preserved by many categorical constructions (e.g., pushouts)
They appear naturally in the study of quotient objects
They form one half of the factorization systems in many categories




The categorical dual of an epimorphism is a monomorphism. That is, an epimorphism in a category \(\mathcal{C}\) is a monomorphism in the opposite category \(\mathcal{C}^{\text{op}}\).

text:
In a category \(\mathcal{C}\), a morphism \(f: A \to B\) is an epimorphism if for any object \(C\) and any pair of morphisms \(g, h: B \to C\), the following implication holds:
\[g \circ f = h \circ f \implies g = h\]
In other words, \(f\) is right-cancellative: it can be “cancelled” from the right side of an equation.

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text: A morphism \(f: A \to B\) is an epimorphism if and only if for every object \(C\), the induced function \[f^*: \text{Hom}(B, C) \to \text{Hom}(A, C)\] defined by \(f^*(g) = g \circ f\) is injective.

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text:
Set: In the category of sets, epimorphisms are exactly the surjective functions
Grp: In the category of groups, epimorphisms are the surjective group homomorphisms
Top: In the category of topological spaces, epimorphisms are the continuous maps with dense image
Vect: In the category of vector spaces over a field, epimorphisms are the surjective linear transformations
Ab: In the category of abelian groups, epimorphisms are the surjective group homomorphisms




Not all epimorphisms are surjective in the usual sense:

Ring: In the category of rings, the inclusion \(\mathbb{Z} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{Q}\) is an epimorphism (as a ring homomorphism) but not surjective
Haus: In the category of Hausdorff spaces, the inclusion \(\mathbb{Q} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is an epimorphism (dense image) but not surjective
Mon: In the category of monoids, there exist non-surjective epimorphisms

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text:
Composition: The composition of two epimorphisms is an epimorphism
Identity: Every identity morphism is an epimorphism
Decomposition: If \(g \circ f\) is an epimorphism, then \(g\) is an epimorphism





Retractions: Every retraction (right inverse) is an epimorphism
Isomorphisms: Every isomorphism is both a monomorphism and an epimorphism
Coequalizers: Every coequalizer is an epimorphism

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text:
In categories with additional structure, we can define special types of epimorphisms:

Regular epimorphism: A coequalizer of some pair of parallel morphisms
Strong epimorphism: An epimorphism that has the right lifting property with respect to monomorphisms
Extremal epimorphism: An epimorphism that doesn’t factor through any proper monomorphism
Split epimorphism: An epimorphism that has a right inverse (i.e., a retraction)

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text:
Epimorphisms are fundamental in category theory because:

They generalize the notion of “surjective” to arbitrary categories
They are preserved by many categorical constructions (e.g., pushouts)
They appear naturally in the study of quotient objects
They form one half of the factorization systems in many categories

title: Definition: Epimorphism
text: The categorical dual of an epimorphism is a monomorphism. That is, an epimorphism in a category \(\mathcal{C}\) is a monomorphism in the opposite category \(\mathcal{C}^{\text{op}}\).

title: Definition: Natural Transformation
text:
A natural transformation provides a way to transform one Functor into another while respecting the internal structure of the categories involved.


Let \(F, G: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D}\) be two functors between categories \(\mathcal{C}\) and \(\mathcal{D}\). A natural transformation \(\eta: F \Rightarrow G\) consists of:

For each object \(X\) in \(\mathcal{C}\), a Morphism \(\eta_X: F(X) \to G(X)\) in \(\mathcal{D}\)

Such that for every morphism \(f: X \to Y\) in \(\mathcal{C}\), the following diagram commutes:
F(X) --F(f)--> F(Y)
 |              |
η_X            η_Y
 ↓              ↓
G(X) --G(f)--> G(Y)
That is, \(\eta_Y \circ F(f) = G(f) \circ \eta_X\).




Each morphism \(\eta_X\) is called a component of the natural transformation
The commutativity condition is called the naturality condition
When this condition holds, we say that \(\eta\) is natural in X





Natural Isomorphism: A natural transformation where every component \(\eta_X\) is an isomorphism
Identity Natural Transformation: For any functor \(F\), the identity transformation \(\text{id}_F\) has components \((\text{id}_F)_X = \text{id}_{F(X)}\)




Natural transformations can be composed: - Vertical Composition: If \(\eta: F \Rightarrow G\) and \(\mu: G \Rightarrow H\), then \(\mu \circ \eta: F \Rightarrow H\) - Horizontal Composition: Natural transformations can also be composed with functors

title: Definition: Category
text:
A category is a mathematical structure consisting of objects and morphisms (arrows) between them, with a composition operation satisfying certain axioms. Categories can be viewed as Directed Graphs with additional structure: objects as vertices, morphisms as directed edges, and composition as a way to combine paths.


A category \(\mathcal{C}\) consists of:

A collection of objects, denoted \(\text{Ob}(\mathcal{C})\)
For each pair of objects \(A, B\), a Set of morphisms (or arrows) from \(A\) to \(B\), denoted \(\text{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B)\)
For each triple of objects \(A, B, C\), a composition operation: \[\circ: \text{Hom}(B, C) \times \text{Hom}(A, B) \to \text{Hom}(A, C)\]

satisfying:



Identity: For each object \(A\), there exists an identity morphism \(\text{id}_A \in \text{Hom}(A, A)\) such that:

\(f \circ \text{id}_A = f\) for all \(f: A \to B\)
\(\text{id}_A \circ g = g\) for all \(g: B \to A\)

Associativity: For morphisms \(f: A \to B\), \(g: B \to C\), \(h: C \to D\): \[h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f\]






Set: Objects are sets, morphisms are functions
Grp: Objects are groups, morphisms are group homomorphisms
Top: Objects are topological spaces, morphisms are continuous functions
Vect: Objects are vector spaces, morphisms are linear transformations

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text: An isomorphism in a Category is a Morphism that has a two-sided inverse. Isomorphic objects are considered “the same” from the categorical perspective.

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Formal Definition
A morphism \(f: A \to B\) in a category \(\mathcal{C}\) is an isomorphism if there exists a morphism \(g: B \to A\) such that: 1. \(g \circ f = \text{id}_A\) 2. \(f \circ g = \text{id}_B\)
The morphism \(g\) is called the inverse of \(f\), denoted \(f^{-1}\).

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Properties

Uniqueness of Inverse: If \(f\) has an inverse, it is unique
Symmetry: If \(f: A \to B\) is an isomorphism, then \(f^{-1}: B \to A\) is also an isomorphism
Composition: The Composition of isomorphisms is an isomorphism:

If \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to C\) are isomorphisms
Then \(g \circ f: A \to C\) is an isomorphism with \((g \circ f)^{-1} = f^{-1} \circ g^{-1}\)

Mono and Epi: Every isomorphism is both a monomorphism and an epimorphism

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Isomorphic Objects
Objects \(A\) and \(B\) are isomorphic, written \(A \cong B\), if there exists an isomorphism \(f: A \to B\).
Isomorphism is an equivalence relation: - Reflexive: \(A \cong A\) via \(\text{id}_A\) - Symmetric: \(A \cong B\) implies \(B \cong A\) - Transitive: \(A \cong B\) and \(B \cong C\) implies \(A \cong C\)

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Examples in Different Categories

Set

Isomorphisms are bijective functions
Two sets are isomorphic iff they have the same cardinality



Group

Isomorphisms are bijective group homomorphisms
Example: \((\mathbb{Z}, +) \cong (2\mathbb{Z}, +)\) via \(n \mapsto 2n\)



Top (Topological Spaces)

Isomorphisms are homeomorphisms (continuous bijections with continuous inverse)
Example: Open interval \((0,1)\) is homeomorphic to \(\mathbb{R}\)



Vect (Vector Spaces)

Isomorphisms are invertible linear transformations
Finite-dimensional spaces are isomorphic iff they have the same dimension

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Special Types

Automorphism
An isomorphism from an object to itself: \(f: A \to A\)


Natural Isomorphism
An isomorphism in the functor category (see Natural Transformation)

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Categorical Perspective

Isomorphism captures the idea of “sameness” in a category
Category theory studies properties invariant under isomorphism
The principle of equivalence: isomorphic objects are indistinguishable within the category

title: Definition: Isomorphism
text:
Non-Examples

In Set: Injective but non-surjective functions
In Group: Non-bijective homomorphisms
Continuous functions that aren’t homeomorphisms

title: Definition: Fundamental Group
text:
The fundamental group of a topological space is the group of equivalence classes of loops based at a fixed point, where two loops are considered equivalent if one can be continuously deformed into the other.


Let \((X, \tau)\) be a topological space and \(x_0 \in X\) a basepoint. A loop based at \(x_0\) is a continuous function \(\gamma: [0,1] \to X\) such that \(\gamma(0) = \gamma(1) = x_0\).
Two loops \(\gamma_0, \gamma_1\) based at \(x_0\) are homotopic (written \(\gamma_0 \simeq \gamma_1\)) if there exists a continuous function \(H: [0,1] \times [0,1] \to X\) such that: - \(H(s,0) = \gamma_0(s)\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - \(H(s,1) = \gamma_1(s)\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - \(H(0,t) = H(1,t) = x_0\) for all \(t \in [0,1]\)
The fundamental group \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is the set of equivalence classes of loops based at \(x_0\) under homotopy.



The group operation on \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is given by concatenation of loops:
For loops \(\gamma_1, \gamma_2\) based at \(x_0\), their concatenation \(\gamma_1 * \gamma_2\) is defined by:
\[(\gamma_1 * \gamma_2)(s) = \begin{cases}
\gamma_1(2s) & \text{if } 0 \leq s \leq 1/2 \\
\gamma_2(2s-1) & \text{if } 1/2 \leq s \leq 1
\end{cases}\]
This operation is well-defined on homotopy classes and makes \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) into a group with: - Identity: The constant loop \(e(s) = x_0\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - Inverse: For a loop \(\gamma\), its inverse \(\gamma^{-1}(s) = \gamma(1-s)\)




Topological Invariant: If \(f: X \to Y\) is a homeomorphism, then \(\pi_1(X, x_0) \cong \pi_1(Y, f(x_0))\)
Path-Connected Spaces: For path-connected spaces, the fundamental group is independent of basepoint up to isomorphism
Simply Connected: A space \(X\) is called simply connected if it is path-connected and \(\pi_1(X, x_0) = \{e\}\) (the trivial group)
Abelianization: The abelianization of \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is isomorphic to the first homology group \(H_1(X)\)





\(\pi_1(\mathbb{R}^n, x_0) = \{e\}\) for all \(n \geq 1\)
\(\pi_1(S^1, x_0) \cong \mathbb{Z}\), where \(S^1\) is the circle (this is the (free?) group on one generator)

title: Definition: Fundamental Group
text:
Let \((X, \tau)\) be a topological space and \(x_0 \in X\) a basepoint. A loop based at \(x_0\) is a continuous function \(\gamma: [0,1] \to X\) such that \(\gamma(0) = \gamma(1) = x_0\).
Two loops \(\gamma_0, \gamma_1\) based at \(x_0\) are homotopic (written \(\gamma_0 \simeq \gamma_1\)) if there exists a continuous function \(H: [0,1] \times [0,1] \to X\) such that: - \(H(s,0) = \gamma_0(s)\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - \(H(s,1) = \gamma_1(s)\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - \(H(0,t) = H(1,t) = x_0\) for all \(t \in [0,1]\)
The fundamental group \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is the set of equivalence classes of loops based at \(x_0\) under homotopy.

title: Definition: Fundamental Group
text:
The group operation on \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is given by concatenation of loops:
For loops \(\gamma_1, \gamma_2\) based at \(x_0\), their concatenation \(\gamma_1 * \gamma_2\) is defined by:
\[(\gamma_1 * \gamma_2)(s) = \begin{cases}
\gamma_1(2s) & \text{if } 0 \leq s \leq 1/2 \\
\gamma_2(2s-1) & \text{if } 1/2 \leq s \leq 1
\end{cases}\]
This operation is well-defined on homotopy classes and makes \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) into a group with: - Identity: The constant loop \(e(s) = x_0\) for all \(s \in [0,1]\) - Inverse: For a loop \(\gamma\), its inverse \(\gamma^{-1}(s) = \gamma(1-s)\)

title: Definition: Fundamental Group
text:
Topological Invariant: If \(f: X \to Y\) is a homeomorphism, then \(\pi_1(X, x_0) \cong \pi_1(Y, f(x_0))\)
Path-Connected Spaces: For path-connected spaces, the fundamental group is independent of basepoint up to isomorphism
Simply Connected: A space \(X\) is called simply connected if it is path-connected and \(\pi_1(X, x_0) = \{e\}\) (the trivial group)
Abelianization: The abelianization of \(\pi_1(X, x_0)\) is isomorphic to the first homology group \(H_1(X)\)

title: Definition: Connected Space
text:
A Topological Space is connected if it cannot be represented as the union of two disjoint non-empty Open Set sets.


A topological space \((X, \tau)\) is connected if the only subsets of \(X\) that are both open and Closed Set are \(\emptyset\) and \(X\) itself.
Equivalently, \(X\) is connected if and only if: - \(X\) cannot be written as \(X = U \cup V\) where \(U, V\) are non-empty, disjoint open sets - There does not exist a continuous surjection \(f: X \to \{0, 1\}\) (with discrete topology)



A space is disconnected if it can be written as \(X = U \cup V\) where: - \(U, V\) are non-empty - \(U \cap V = \emptyset\) - \(U, V\) are both open (or equivalently, both closed)




The continuous image of a connected space is connected
The closure of a connected set is connected
If \(\{A_i\}\) is a collection of connected sets with \(\bigcap A_i \neq \emptyset\), then \(\bigcup A_i\) is connected
A space is connected if and only if every continuous function to \(\{0, 1\}\) is constant





The real line \(\mathbb{R}\) is connected
Any interval \([a, b]\), \((a, b)\), \([a, b)\) in \(\mathbb{R}\) is connected
The space \(\mathbb{R} \setminus \{0\}\) is disconnected




A stronger notion is path-connected: a space where any two points can be joined by a continuous path. Every path-connected space is connected, but not conversely. Path-connectedness is important for the fundamental group.

title: Theorem: Intermediate Value Theorem
text:
A Continuity function from a Connected Space space to the real numbers attains all intermediate values.


Let \(f: X \to \mathbb{R}\) be a continuous function where \(X\) is a connected topological space. If \(a, b \in f(X)\) with \(a < b\), then for every \(c \in (a, b)\), there exists \(x \in X\) such that \(f(x) = c\).



For the special case where \(X = [a, b] \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) is a closed interval:
If \(f: [a, b] \to \mathbb{R}\) is continuous and \(f(a) < c < f(b)\) (or \(f(b) < c < f(a)\)), then there exists \(x_0 \in (a, b)\) such that \(f(x_0) = c\).



The proof relies on the fact that: 1. The continuous image of a connected space is connected 2. Connected subsets of \(\mathbb{R}\) are intervals 3. Intervals contain all intermediate values




Finding roots of continuous functions
Proving existence of fixed points
Establishing properties of continuous functions on intervals
Analysis of differential equations




Any polynomial of odd degree has at least one real root, since: - \(\lim_{x \to \infty} P(x) = \infty\) and \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} P(x) = -\infty\) (or vice versa) - By IVT, \(P(x) = 0\) for some \(x\)

title: Definition: Topological Space
text:
A topological space is a Set \(X\) together with a collection \(\tau\) of subsets of \(X\) satisfying the following axioms:


The collection \(\tau\) must satisfy:

Empty set and whole space: \(\emptyset \in \tau\) and \(X \in \tau\)
Arbitrary unions: If \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) is any collection of sets in \(\tau\), then \[\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i \in \tau\]
Finite intersections: If \(U_1, U_2, \ldots, U_n \in \tau\), then \[\bigcap_{i=1}^{n} U_i \in \tau\]





The collection \(\tau\) is called a topology on \(X\)
The sets in \(\tau\) are called open sets
The pair \((X, \tau)\) is called a topological space
When the topology is clear from context, we may simply refer to “the topological space \(X\)”





Discrete topology: \(\tau = \mathcal{P}(X)\) (all subsets are open)
Indiscrete topology: \(\tau = \{\emptyset, X\}\) (only the empty set and \(X\) are open)
Standard topology on \(\mathbb{R}\): Open sets are unions of open intervals




Key properties that follow from these axioms:

The union of any collection of open sets is open
The intersection of finitely many open sets is open
Complements of open sets are called closed sets

title: Theorem: Union of Open Sets
text:
Let \((X, \tau)\) be a Topological Space. Then the union of any collection of open sets is open.


If \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) is any collection of open sets (where \(I\) is an arbitrary index set), then \[\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i \in \tau\]



This follows directly from the definition of a topology.
Let \(\{U_i\}_{i \in I}\) be an arbitrary collection of sets where each \(U_i \in \tau\).
By the second axiom in the definition of a Topological Space, the arbitrary union of sets in \(\tau\) must also be in \(\tau\).
Therefore, \(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i \in \tau\), which means \(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i\) is open. \(\square\)



This theorem holds for arbitrary unions, including: - Finite unions - Countably infinite unions - Uncountably infinite unions
However, the analogous statement for intersections is not true in general. Only finite intersections of open sets are guaranteed to be open.




In \(\mathbb{R}\) with the standard topology:

\(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} (-\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}) = (-1, 1)\) is open
\(\bigcup_{x \in (0,1)} (x - \frac{1}{2}, x + \frac{1}{2}) = (-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2})\) is open

Counter-example for infinite intersections:

\(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} (-\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}) = \{0\}\) is not open in \(\mathbb{R}\)





This property is fundamental in: - Defining basis and subbasis for topologies - Constructing new topological spaces - Proving continuity of functions

title: Theorem: Every Metric Space is Hausdorff
text:
Statement: Every Metric Space \((X, d)\) with the metric topology is a Hausdorff Space space.


Let \((X, d)\) be a metric space and let \(x, y \in X\) be two distinct points with \(x \neq y\).
Since \(x \neq y\), by the identity of indiscernibles property of metrics, we have \(d(x, y) > 0\).
Let \(r = \frac{d(x, y)}{2} > 0\).
Consider the open balls: - \(U = B(x, r) = \{z \in X : d(x, z) < r\}\) - \(V = B(y, r) = \{z \in X : d(y, z) < r\}\)
We claim that \(U \cap V = \emptyset\).
Proof by contradiction: Suppose there exists \(z \in U \cap V\). Then: - \(z \in U\) implies \(d(x, z) < r = \frac{d(x, y)}{2}\) - \(z \in V\) implies \(d(y, z) < r = \frac{d(x, y)}{2}\)
By the triangle inequality: \[d(x, y) \leq d(x, z) + d(z, y) = d(x, z) + d(y, z) < \frac{d(x, y)}{2} + \frac{d(x, y)}{2} = d(x, y)\]
This gives us \(d(x, y) < d(x, y)\), which is a contradiction.
Therefore \(U \cap V = \emptyset\), and we have found disjoint open neighborhoods separating \(x\) and \(y\).
Since \(x\) and \(y\) were arbitrary distinct points, \((X, d)\) is Hausdorff. \(\square\)



This theorem has several important implications:

Uniqueness of limits: In any metric space, convergent sequences have unique limits
Closed singletons: Every point \(\{x\}\) in a metric space forms a closed set
Nice separation properties: Metric spaces automatically satisfy all the lower separation axioms (\(T_0\), \(T_1\), \(T_2\))





Metric Space - The structure that guarantees the Hausdorff property
Hausdorff Space - The separation property satisfied by all metric spaces
Real Line with Standard Metric - A concrete example of a metric space that is Hausdorff

title: Definition: Open Set
text:
Let \((X, \tau)\) be a Topological Space. A subset \(U \subseteq X\) is called an open set if and only if \(U \in \tau\).


By the definition of a topology, open sets have the following properties:

The empty set \(\emptyset\) and the entire space \(X\) are open
Any union of open sets is open
Any finite intersection of open sets is open







Open intervals \((a, b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a < x < b\}\) are open sets
Closed intervals \([a, b]\) are not open sets
Half-open intervals \([a, b)\) and \((a, b]\) are not open sets
The entire real line \(\mathbb{R}\) is open
Any union of open intervals is open





Every subset is an open set





Only \(\emptyset\) and \(X\) are open sets





Open sets can be thought of as sets where every point has some “wiggle room” around it that stays within the set. This intuition is formalized in metric spaces, where a set is open if every point has an open ball around it contained in the set.

title: Definition: Function
text:
A function from a set \(A\) to a set \(B\) is a relation that assigns to each element of \(A\) exactly one element of \(B\).


A function \(f\) from \(A\) to \(B\) (written \(f: A \to B\)) is a subset of the Cartesian product \(A \times B\) such that:

Existence: For every \(a \in A\), there exists at least one \(b \in B\) such that \((a, b) \in f\)
Uniqueness: For every \(a \in A\), if \((a, b_1) \in f\) and \((a, b_2) \in f\), then \(b_1 = b_2\)





Domain: The set \(A\) is called the domain of \(f\), denoted \(\text{dom}(f) = A\)
Codomain: The set \(B\) is called the codomain of \(f\)
Value: If \((a, b) \in f\), we write \(f(a) = b\) and say “\(b\) is the value of \(f\) at \(a\)”
Image/Range: The set \(\{f(a) : a \in A\} = \{b \in B : \exists a \in A, f(a) = b\}\) is called the image or range of \(f\), denoted \(\text{im}(f)\) or \(\text{range}(f)\)






A function \(f: A \to B\) is injective if different elements in \(A\) map to different elements in \(B\):
\[\forall a_1, a_2 \in A: f(a_1) = f(a_2) \implies a_1 = a_2\]
In category theory, the concept of injective function is generalized to monomorphism.



A function \(f: A \to B\) is surjective if every element in \(B\) is the image of at least one element in \(A\):
\[\forall b \in B: \exists a \in A \text{ such that } f(a) = b\]
Equivalently, \(f\) is surjective if \(\text{im}(f) = B\).



A function \(f: A \to B\) is bijective if it is both injective and surjective. A bijective function has an inverse function \(f^{-1}: B \to A\).





Identity function: \(\text{id}_A: A \to A\) defined by \(\text{id}_A(a) = a\) for all \(a \in A\)
Constant function: A function \(f: A \to B\) where \(f(a) = b_0\) for some fixed \(b_0 \in B\) and all \(a \in A\)
Inclusion function: If \(A \subseteq B\), the inclusion \(i: A \to B\) defined by \(i(a) = a\) for all \(a \in A\)





Composition: If \(f: A \to B\) and \(g: B \to C\), then \(g \circ f: A \to C\) is defined by \((g \circ f)(a) = g(f(a))\)
Equality: Two functions \(f, g: A \to B\) are equal if \(f(a) = g(a)\) for all \(a \in A\)

title: Definition: Equivalence Relation
text:
An equivalence relation on a set \(A\) is a relation \(\sim\) on \(A\) that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.


A relation \(\sim\) on a set \(A\) is an equivalence relation if and only if it satisfies the following three properties:


For all \(a \in A\): \[a \sim a\]
Every element is related to itself.



For all \(a, b \in A\): \[a \sim b \implies b \sim a\]
If \(a\) is related to \(b\), then \(b\) is related to \(a\).



For all \(a, b, c \in A\): \[(a \sim b \text{ and } b \sim c) \implies a \sim c\]
If \(a\) is related to \(b\) and \(b\) is related to \(c\), then \(a\) is related to \(c\).




Given an equivalence relation \(\sim\) on a set \(A\), for each element \(a \in A\), the equivalence class of \(a\) is:
\[[a] = \{x \in A : x \sim a\}\]



Non-empty: \(a \in [a]\) for all \(a \in A\) (by reflexivity)
Equal or disjoint: For any \(a, b \in A\), either \([a] = [b]\) or \([a] \cap [b] = \emptyset\)
Partition: The set of all equivalence classes forms a partition of \(A\): \[A = \bigcup_{a \in A} [a]\]





The quotient set of \(A\) by \(\sim\), denoted \(A/\sim\), is the set of all equivalence classes:
\[A/\sim = \{[a] : a \in A\}\]





The relation \(=\) on any set is an equivalence relation: - Reflexive: \(a = a\) - Symmetric: \(a = b \implies b = a\) - Transitive: \(a = b\) and \(b = c \implies a = c\)



For a fixed positive integer \(n\), the relation \(\equiv_n\) on \(\mathbb{Z}\) defined by: \[a \equiv_n b \iff n \mid (a - b)\]
is an equivalence relation. The equivalence classes are the residue classes modulo \(n\).



On the set of \(n \times n\) matrices, the relation “is similar to” defined by: \[A \sim B \iff \exists \text{ invertible } P \text{ such that } B = P^{-1}AP\]
is an equivalence relation.



On the set of lines in a plane, the relation “is parallel to” is an equivalence relation (where we consider a line parallel to itself).






There is a bijective correspondence between: 1. Equivalence relations on a set \(A\) 2. Partitions of the set \(A\)
Every equivalence relation induces a partition, and every partition defines an equivalence relation.

Abstract algebra: Quotient groups, quotient rings, and quotient spaces
Topology: Quotient topologies and identification spaces
Computer science: Union-find data structures, type equivalence

title: Definition: Set
text:
A set is a well-defined collection of distinct objects, called elements or members of the set.



If \(a\) is an element of set \(A\), we write \(a \in A\)
If \(a\) is not an element of set \(A\), we write \(a \notin A\)
Sets are typically denoted by capital letters: \(A, B, C, \ldots\)
Elements are typically denoted by lowercase letters: \(a, b, c, \ldots\)





Roster notation: List all elements between braces

Example: \(A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}\)

Set-builder notation: Specify a property that elements must satisfy

Example: \(B = \{x \in \mathbb{N} : x < 6\}\)






Distinctness: Each element appears only once in a set
Orderless: The order of elements does not matter

\(\{1, 2, 3\} = \{3, 1, 2\}\)

Well-defined: For any object, it must be clear whether it is an element of the set or not





Empty set: The set with no elements, denoted \(\emptyset\) or \(\{\}\)
Singleton: A set with exactly one element

title: Definition: Power Set
text:
The power set of a set \(A\), denoted \(\mathcal{P}(A)\) or \(2^A\), is the set of all subsets of \(A\).


\[\mathcal{P}(A) = \{B : B \subseteq A\}\]
In other words, \(B \in \mathcal{P}(A)\) if and only if every element of \(B\) is also an element of \(A\).




Always contains the empty set: \(\emptyset \in \mathcal{P}(A)\) for any set \(A\)
Always contains the original set: \(A \in \mathcal{P}(A)\)
Cardinality: If \(|A| = n\) (finite), then \(|\mathcal{P}(A)| = 2^n\)
Ordering: \(\mathcal{P}(A)\) forms a partially ordered set under inclusion





If \(A = \emptyset\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset\}\)
If \(A = \{1\}\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{1\}\}\)
If \(A = \{1, 2\}\), then \(\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{1\}, \{2\}, \{1, 2\}\}\)
If \(A = \{a, b, c\}\), then: \[\mathcal{P}(A) = \{\emptyset, \{a\}, \{b\}, \{c\}, \{a,b\}, \{a,c\}, \{b,c\}, \{a,b,c\}\}\]





\(A \subseteq B\) if and only if \(\mathcal{P}(A) \subseteq \mathcal{P}(B)\)
\(\mathcal{P}(A \cap B) = \mathcal{P}(A) \cap \mathcal{P}(B)\)
\(\mathcal{P}(A) \cup \mathcal{P}(B) \subseteq \mathcal{P}(A \cup B)\) (but not always equal)

title: Definition: Union
text: The union of two Sets \(A\) and \(B\), denoted \(A \cup B\), is the set containing all elements that belong to either \(A\) or \(B\) (or both).

title: Definition: Union
text:
Formal Definition
\[A \cup B = \{x : x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\}\]
Equivalently, using logical notation: \[x \in A \cup B \iff (x \in A) \lor (x \in B)\]

title: Definition: Union
text:
Properties

Commutativity: \(A \cup B = B \cup A\)
Associativity: \((A \cup B) \cup C = A \cup (B \cup C)\)
Identity: \(A \cup \emptyset = A\)
Idempotence: \(A \cup A = A\)
Absorption: If \(A \subseteq B\), then \(A \cup B = B\)

title: Definition: Union
text:
Generalized Union
For a collection of sets \(\{A_i : i \in I\}\): \[\bigcup_{i \in I} A_i = \{x : \exists i \in I, x \in A_i\}\]
Special cases: - Finite union: \(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i = A_1 \cup A_2 \cup \cdots \cup A_n\) - Infinite union: \(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} A_i\)

title: Definition: Union
text:
Examples

\(\{1, 2, 3\} \cup \{3, 4, 5\} = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}\)
\(\mathbb{Q} \cup \mathbb{I} = \mathbb{R}\) (rationals union irrationals equals reals)
For intervals: \([0, 2] \cup [1, 3] = [0, 3]\)

title: Definition: Union
text:
Relationship with Other Operations

De Morgan’s Laws: \((A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c\) (see De Morgan’s Laws)
Distributivity: \(A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)\)
Cardinality: \(|A \cup B| = |A| + |B| - |A \cap B|\) (see Inclusion-Exclusion Principle)

title: Theorem: De Morgan’s Laws
text: De Morgan’s Laws describe the relationship between Union, Intersection, and set complement. They state that the complement of a union equals the intersection of complements, and the complement of an intersection equals the union of complements.

title: Theorem: De Morgan’s Laws
text:
Statement
For any Sets \(A\) and \(B\) in a universal set \(U\):

\((A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c\)
\((A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c\)

Where \(X^c\) denotes the complement of set \(X\) in \(U\).

title: Theorem: De Morgan’s Laws
text:
Proof

First Law: \((A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c\)
We prove by showing mutual subset inclusion.
Part 1: \((A \cup B)^c \subseteq A^c \cap B^c\)
Let \(x \in (A \cup B)^c\). Then: - \(x \notin A \cup B\) - \(x \notin A\) and \(x \notin B\) (by definition of union) - \(x \in A^c\) and \(x \in B^c\) (by definition of complement) - \(x \in A^c \cap B^c\) (by definition of intersection)
Part 2: \(A^c \cap B^c \subseteq (A \cup B)^c\)
Let \(x \in A^c \cap B^c\). Then: - \(x \in A^c\) and \(x \in B^c\) - \(x \notin A\) and \(x \notin B\) - \(x \notin A \cup B\) - \(x \in (A \cup B)^c\)
Therefore, \((A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c\).


Second Law: \((A \cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c\)
The proof follows a similar structure using the logical equivalence: \(\neg(P \land Q) \equiv \neg P \lor \neg Q\)

title: Theorem: De Morgan’s Laws
text:
Generalized De Morgan’s Laws
For any collection of sets \(\{A_i : i \in I\}\):

\(\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} A_i\right)^c = \bigcap_{i \in I} A_i^c\)
\(\left(\bigcap_{i \in I} A_i\right)^c = \bigcup_{i \in I} A_i^c\)

title: Theorem: De Morgan’s Laws
text:
Applications

Logic: Corresponding laws in Boolean algebra and propositional logic
Probability: \(P(A^c \cap B^c) = P((A \cup B)^c) = 1 - P(A \cup B)\)
Computer Science: Circuit design and Boolean function simplification
Set Theory: Simplifying complex set expressions

title: Definition: Subset
text: A Set \(A\) is a subset of a set \(B\), denoted \(A \subseteq B\), if every element of \(A\) is also an element of \(B\).

title: Definition: Subset
text:
Formal Definition
\[A \subseteq B \iff \forall x (x \in A \implies x \in B)\]
In words: \(A\) is a subset of \(B\) if and only if for all \(x\), if \(x\) is in \(A\), then \(x\) is in \(B\).

title: Definition: Subset
text:
Notation and Terminology

\(A \subseteq B\): “\(A\) is a subset of \(B\)” or “\(A\) is contained in \(B\)”
\(B \supseteq A\): “\(B\) is a superset of \(A\)” or “\(B\) contains \(A\)”
\(A \subset B\): “\(A\) is a proper subset of \(B\)” (when \(A \subseteq B\) and \(A \neq B\))
\(A \not\subseteq B\): “\(A\) is not a subset of \(B\)”

title: Definition: Subset
text:
Properties

Reflexivity: Every set is a subset of itself: \(A \subseteq A\)
Transitivity: If \(A \subseteq B\) and \(B \subseteq C\), then \(A \subseteq C\)
Antisymmetry: If \(A \subseteq B\) and \(B \subseteq A\), then \(A = B\)
Empty set: The empty set \(\emptyset\) is a subset of every set

title: Definition: Subset
text:
Examples

\(\{1, 2\} \subseteq \{1, 2, 3, 4\}\)
\(\mathbb{N} \subseteq \mathbb{Z} \subseteq \mathbb{Q} \subseteq \mathbb{R} \subseteq \mathbb{C}\)
For any set \(A\): \(\emptyset \subseteq A \subseteq A\)

title: Definition: Subset
text:
Related Concepts

Power Set: The set of all subsets of a given set
Set equality can be proven by showing mutual subset relations
The subset relation defines a partial order on the power set

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text: The conditional probability of an Event \(A\) given event \(B\) is the probability that \(A\) occurs, given that \(B\) has occurred. It is denoted \(P(A|B)\).

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Formal Definition
Given two events \(A\) and \(B\) in a Probability Space, with \(P(B) > 0\), the conditional probability of \(A\) given \(B\) is:
\[P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}\]

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Intuition

\(P(A|B)\) represents the “updated” probability of \(A\) after learning that \(B\) occurred
We restrict our attention to the subset of outcomes where \(B\) occurs
We rescale probabilities so that \(P(B|B) = 1\)

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Properties

Range: \(0 \leq P(A|B) \leq 1\)
Certainty: \(P(B|B) = 1\) when \(P(B) > 0\)
Impossibility: \(P(\emptyset|B) = 0\)
Subset: If \(A \subseteq B\), then \(P(A|B) = \frac{P(A)}{P(B)}\)

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Multiplication Rule
Rearranging the definition gives: \[P(A \cap B) = P(A|B) \cdot P(B) = P(B|A) \cdot P(A)\]
For multiple events: \[P(A_1 \cap A_2 \cap \cdots \cap A_n) = P(A_1)P(A_2|A_1)P(A_3|A_1 \cap A_2)\cdots P(A_n|A_1 \cap \cdots \cap A_{n-1})\]

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Independence
Events \(A\) and \(B\) are independent if and only if: \[P(A|B) = P(A)\]
This means knowing \(B\) occurred doesn’t change the probability of \(A\).

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Examples

Card Drawing: Drawing an ace from a standard deck

\(P(\text{Ace}) = \frac{4}{52} = \frac{1}{13}\)
\(P(\text{Ace}|\text{Red card}) = \frac{2}{26} = \frac{1}{13}\) (independent)
\(P(\text{Ace}|\text{Face card}) = 0\) (mutually exclusive)

Medical Testing: Disease prevalence and test accuracy

If \(P(\text{Disease}) = 0.01\) and test is 95% accurate
\(P(\text{Positive}|\text{Disease})\) represents sensitivity

title: Definition: Conditional Probability
text:
Related Concepts

Bayes’ Theorem: Relates \(P(A|B)\) and \(P(B|A)\)
Law of Total Probability: Uses conditional probabilities for calculation
Conditional expectation extends this concept to Random Variables

title: Definition: Random Variable
text:
A random variable is a measurable function from a Probability Space to a measurable space.


Given a probability space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\), a random variable is a function \(X: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}\) such that for every Borel set \(B \subseteq \mathbb{R}\):
\[X^{-1}(B) = \{\omega \in \Omega : X(\omega) \in B\} \in \mathcal{F}\]
This condition ensures that we can assign probabilities to events of the form \(\{X \in B\}\).




Discrete Random Variable: Takes countably many values

Characterized by probability mass function (PMF): \(p_X(x) = P(X = x)\)

Continuous Random Variable: Takes uncountably many values

Characterized by probability density function (PDF): \(f_X(x)\) where \(P(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f_X(x) dx\)






Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF): \(F_X(x) = P(X \leq x)\)
Expected Value: \(E[X] = \int_{\Omega} X(\omega) dP(\omega)\)
Variance: \(\text{Var}(X) = E[(X - E[X])^2]\)





Bernoulli distribution (see Binomial Distribution for \(n=1\)): \(X \in \{0, 1\}\) with \(P(X = 1) = p\)
Normal distribution: \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) (where \(\sigma^2\) is the variance)
Poisson distribution: \(P(X = k) = \frac{\lambda^k e^{-\lambda}}{k!}\)

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
The normal distribution (also called the Gaussian distribution) is a continuous probability distribution characterized by its bell-shaped probability density function. It is one of the most important distributions in probability theory and statistics.


A continuous random variable \(X\) follows a normal distribution with parameters \(\mu \in \mathbb{R}\) and \(\sigma^2 > 0\), denoted \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\), if its probability density function is:
\[f_X(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)\]
for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).



The normal distribution is completely characterized by two parameters:

Mean \(\mu\): The expected value of the distribution, which determines the location of the center
Variance \(\sigma^2\): The variance of the distribution, which determines the spread
Standard deviation \(\sigma = \sqrt{\sigma^2}\): The square root of the variance




The standard normal distribution is the special case where \(\mu = 0\) and \(\sigma^2 = 1\), denoted \(Z \sim N(0,1)\). Its probability density function simplifies to:
\[\phi(z) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{z^2}{2}\right)\]
The cumulative distribution function of the standard normal is typically denoted by \(\Phi\):
\[\Phi(z) = \int_{-\infty}^z \phi(t) \, dt = \int_{-\infty}^z \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{t^2}{2}\right) dt\]






Symmetry: The distribution is symmetric about its mean \(\mu\)
Mode: The mode (maximum of the PDF) occurs at \(x = \mu\)
Inflection points: Located at \(x = \mu \pm \sigma\)
Total probability: \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_X(x) \, dx = 1\)




For \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\):

Expected value: \(E[X] = \mu\)
Variance: \(\text{Var}(X) = \sigma^2\)
Moment generating function: \(M_X(t) = \exp(\mu t + \frac{\sigma^2 t^2}{2})\)
Characteristic function: \(\phi_X(t) = \exp(i\mu t - \frac{\sigma^2 t^2}{2})\)




For a normal distribution: - Approximately 68% of values lie within \(\mu \pm \sigma\) - Approximately 95% of values lie within \(\mu \pm 2\sigma\) - Approximately 99.7% of values lie within \(\mu \pm 3\sigma\)




Any normal random variable \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) can be standardized to obtain a standard normal variable:
\[Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim N(0,1)\]
This transformation is crucial for: - Calculating probabilities using standard normal tables - Comparing values from different normal distributions



If \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) and \(Y = aX + b\) where \(a \neq 0\), then:
\[Y \sim N(a\mu + b, a^2\sigma^2)\]



If \(X_1 \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2)\) and \(X_2 \sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)\) are independent, then:
\[X_1 + X_2 \sim N(\mu_1 + \mu_2, \sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2)\]
More generally, for independent \(X_i \sim N(\mu_i, \sigma_i^2)\):
\[\sum_{i=1}^n X_i \sim N\left(\sum_{i=1}^n \mu_i, \sum_{i=1}^n \sigma_i^2\right)\]





The Central Limit Theorem establishes that the normalized sum of independent random variables converges to a normal distribution, explaining the ubiquity of the normal distribution in nature.




Chi-squared: If \(Z \sim N(0,1)\), then \(Z^2 \sim \chi^2_1\)
Log-normal: If \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\), then \(e^X\) follows a log-normal distribution
Multivariate normal: Generalization to multiple dimensions





The normal distribution appears in numerous contexts:

Natural phenomena: Heights, weights, measurement errors
Statistical inference: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing
Finance: Asset returns (under certain models)
Engineering: Signal processing, quality control
Physics: Brownian motion, diffusion processes





Central Limit Theorem - Convergence to normality
Law of Large Numbers - Convergence of averages
Bayes’ Theorem - Using normal priors

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
Any normal random variable \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) can be standardized to obtain a standard normal variable:
\[Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim N(0,1)\]
This transformation is crucial for: - Calculating probabilities using standard normal tables - Comparing values from different normal distributions

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
If \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) and \(Y = aX + b\) where \(a \neq 0\), then:
\[Y \sim N(a\mu + b, a^2\sigma^2)\]

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
If \(X_1 \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2)\) and \(X_2 \sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)\) are independent, then:
\[X_1 + X_2 \sim N(\mu_1 + \mu_2, \sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2)\]
More generally, for independent \(X_i \sim N(\mu_i, \sigma_i^2)\):
\[\sum_{i=1}^n X_i \sim N\left(\sum_{i=1}^n \mu_i, \sum_{i=1}^n \sigma_i^2\right)\]

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
The Central Limit Theorem establishes that the normalized sum of independent random variables converges to a normal distribution, explaining the ubiquity of the normal distribution in nature.




Chi-squared: If \(Z \sim N(0,1)\), then \(Z^2 \sim \chi^2_1\)
Log-normal: If \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\), then \(e^X\) follows a log-normal distribution
Multivariate normal: Generalization to multiple dimensions

title: Definition: Normal Distribution
text:
The normal distribution appears in numerous contexts:

Natural phenomena: Heights, weights, measurement errors
Statistical inference: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing
Finance: Asset returns (under certain models)
Engineering: Signal processing, quality control
Physics: Brownian motion, diffusion processes

title: Definition: Probability Space
text:
A probability space is a mathematical construct that provides a formal model for random phenomena.


A probability space is a triple \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\) where:

Sample space \(\Omega\): A Set of all possible outcomes
σ-algebra \(\mathcal{F}\): A collection of subsets of \(\Omega\) (events) satisfying:

\(\Omega \in \mathcal{F}\)
If \(A \in \mathcal{F}\), then \(A^c \in \mathcal{F}\) (closed under complements)
If \(A_1, A_2, ... \in \mathcal{F}\), then \(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} A_i \in \mathcal{F}\) (closed under countable unions)

Probability measure \(P: \mathcal{F} \to [0,1]\) satisfying:

\(P(\Omega) = 1\) (normalization)
\(P(A) \geq 0\) for all \(A \in \mathcal{F}\) (non-negativity)
For disjoint events \(A_1, A_2, ...\): \(P(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} A_i) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} P(A_i)\) (countable additivity)






\(P(\emptyset) = 0\)
\(P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)\)
If \(A \subseteq B\), then \(P(A) \leq P(B)\)
\(P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)\)





Coin flip: \(\Omega = \{H, T\}\), \(\mathcal{F} = 2^{\Omega}\), \(P(H) = P(T) = 1/2\)
Die roll: \(\Omega = \{1,2,3,4,5,6\}\), with uniform probability
Continuous: \(\Omega = [0,1]\) with Lebesgue measure

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text: Bayes’ Theorem provides a way to calculate Conditional Probability in the “reverse” direction. It relates \(P(A|B)\) to \(P(B|A)\), allowing us to update beliefs based on new evidence.

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Statement
For Events \(A\) and \(B\) with \(P(A) > 0\) and \(P(B) > 0\):
\[P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)}\]

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Alternative Forms

Using Law of Total Probability
If \(\{A_1, A_2, ..., A_n\}\) form a partition of the sample space:
\[P(A_i|B) = \frac{P(B|A_i) \cdot P(A_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^n P(B|A_j) \cdot P(A_j)}\]


Binary Case
For event \(A\) and its complement \(A^c\):
\[P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B|A) \cdot P(A) + P(B|A^c) \cdot P(A^c)}\]

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Proof
From the definition of conditional probability: 1. \(P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}\) 2. \(P(B|A) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(A)}\)
From (2): \(P(A \cap B) = P(B|A) \cdot P(A)\)
Substituting into (1): \[P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)}\]

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Terminology

\(P(A)\): Prior probability of \(A\)
\(P(A|B)\): Posterior probability of \(A\) given evidence \(B\)
\(P(B|A)\): Likelihood of observing \(B\) given \(A\)
\(P(B)\): Marginal probability or normalizing constant

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Applications

Medical Diagnosis

\(A\): Patient has disease
\(B\): Test is positive
Calculate \(P(\text{Disease}|\text{Positive test})\) from known test accuracy



Machine Learning

Naive Bayes classifiers
Bayesian inference and parameter estimation
Updating model beliefs with new data



Example: Medical Test
Given: - Disease prevalence: \(P(D) = 0.001\) (0.1%) - Test sensitivity: \(P(+|D) = 0.99\) (99%) - Test specificity: \(P(-|D^c) = 0.95\), so \(P(+|D^c) = 0.05\)
Find \(P(D|+)\): \[P(D|+) = \frac{0.99 \times 0.001}{0.99 \times 0.001 + 0.05 \times 0.999} = \frac{0.00099}{0.05094} \approx 0.0194\]
Despite a positive test, the probability of having the disease is only about 1.94%!

title: Theorem: Bayes’ Theorem
text:
Bayesian Updating
Bayes’ theorem enables iterative belief updating: 1. Start with prior \(P(A)\) 2. Observe evidence \(B\) 3. Update to posterior \(P(A|B)\) 4. Use posterior as new prior for next observation

title: Theorem: Central Limit Theorem
text:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is one of the most fundamental results in probability theory, stating that the distribution of the normalized sum of independent random variables converges to a normal distribution.


Let \(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n\) be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) random variables with: - Finite expected value: \(\mu = E[X_i] < \infty\) - Finite variance: \(\sigma^2 = \text{Var}(X_i) < \infty\), where \(\sigma > 0\)
Define: - Sample mean: \(\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\) - Standardized sum: \(Z_n = \frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n X_i - n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}\)
Then for any \(z \in \mathbb{R}\): \[\lim_{n \to \infty} P(Z_n \leq z) = \Phi(z)\]
where \(\Phi(z) = \int_{-\infty}^z \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-t^2/2} dt\) is the cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution.



The distribution of \(\bar{X}_n\) is approximately normal for large \(n\): \[\bar{X}_n \stackrel{d}{\approx} N\left(\mu, \frac{\sigma^2}{n}\right)\]



The classical proof uses characteristic functions:

The characteristic function of \(Z_n\) is: \[\phi_{Z_n}(t) = \left[\phi_X\left(\frac{t}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}\right) \cdot e^{-it\mu/(\sigma\sqrt{n})}\right]^n\]
Using Taylor expansion of \(\phi_X\) around 0: \[\phi_X(s) = 1 + is\mu - \frac{s^2(\mu^2 + \sigma^2)}{2} + o(s^2)\]
After substitution and simplification: \[\phi_{Z_n}(t) = \left(1 - \frac{t^2}{2n} + o\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)\right)^n\]
Taking the limit: \[\lim_{n \to \infty} \phi_{Z_n}(t) = e^{-t^2/2}\]

This is the characteristic function of \(N(0,1)\), completing the proof by the continuity theorem.




Statistical Inference: Justifies confidence intervals and hypothesis tests
Quality Control: Process capability analysis in manufacturing
Financial Modeling: Risk assessment and portfolio theory
Scientific Measurement: Error analysis and uncertainty quantification
Monte Carlo Methods: Convergence rate estimation






For \(n\) fair coin flips (Bernoulli(1/2), see Binomial Distribution): - \(\mu = 0.5\), \(\sigma^2 = 0.25\) - The proportion of heads \(\approx N(0.5, 0.25/n)\) for large \(n\)



Sum of \(n\) fair die rolls: - Each roll: \(\mu = 3.5\), \(\sigma^2 = 35/12\) - Average of rolls \(\approx N(3.5, 35/(12n))\) for large \(n\)




While the theorem applies as \(n \to \infty\), in practice: - \(n \geq 30\) is often considered sufficient for a good approximation - For heavily skewed distributions, larger \(n\) may be needed

title: Definition: Probability Distribution
text:
A probability distribution is a mathematical function that describes the likelihood of different outcomes for a Random Variable. It provides a complete characterization of the probabilistic behavior of the random variable.


Given a Probability Space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\) and a random variable \(X: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}\), the probability distribution of \(X\) is the probability measure \(P_X\) on \((\mathbb{R}, \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R}))\) defined by:
\[P_X(B) = P(X^{-1}(B)) = P(\{\omega \in \Omega : X(\omega) \in B\})\]
for all Borel sets \(B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R})\).





For a discrete random variable \(X\) taking values in a countable set \(\{x_1, x_2, x_3, \ldots\}\), the distribution is characterized by the probability mass function (PMF):
\[p_X(x_i) = P(X = x_i)\]
Properties: - \(p_X(x_i) \geq 0\) for all \(i\) - \(\sum_{i} p_X(x_i) = 1\)



For a continuous random variable \(X\), the distribution is characterized by the probability density function (PDF) \(f_X(x)\) such that:
\[P(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f_X(x) \, dx\]
Properties: - \(f_X(x) \geq 0\) for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) - \(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_X(x) \, dx = 1\)




The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable \(X\) is defined as:
\[F_X(x) = P(X \leq x) = P_X((-\infty, x])\]
Properties: 1. Monotonicity: \(F_X\) is non-decreasing 2. Limits: \(\lim_{x \to -\infty} F_X(x) = 0\) and \(\lim_{x \to \infty} F_X(x) = 1\) 3. Right-continuity: \(F_X\) is right-continuous at every point



For a continuous distribution with density \(f_X\): - \(F_X(x) = \int_{-\infty}^x f_X(t) \, dt\) - \(f_X(x) = \frac{d}{dx} F_X(x)\) (where the derivative exists)
For a discrete distribution: - \(F_X(x) = \sum_{x_i \leq x} p_X(x_i)\)
